data.title: Stalin Plaza Gets Shut Down
data.meta_description: This is a pretty strange turn of events. I recently moved to Prague and I live fairly close to Stalin Plaza. I’ve written quite a bit about sacred places in skateboarding, and just last month spoke o…
data.text:
This is a pretty strange turn of events. I recently moved to Prague and I live fairly close to Stalin Plaza. I’ve written quite a bit about sacred places in skateboarding, and just last month spoke on a Panel about iconic skateboard spots at Pushing Boarders. On Thursday I met with a colleague who is a specialist in the Urban Sociology of Prague and we spoke at length about how unique Letná Park and Stalin Plaza is. This spot is one of the most famous and respected European skateboarding locations.

Then just yesterday I get word that the police have moved in, barriers have been put in place with bilingual warning signs. The signs suggest there is some danger at the site, and that trespassing will result in fines.

I looked around Stalin Plaza this morning and took these photos. It was early and very empty. Uncharacteristically empty for a Saturday morning despite it being 10am. An old man who often practices his Tai Chi in the Plaza had already moved on to a new location, colonising the Pétanque court. I eventually spied police stationed at the Metronome who would no doubt intervene if you entered and started skating. No tourists are able to make their way to the lookout spot either...it is entirely deserted.

News reports indicate that the podium is condemned and in danger of collapse. This is the area where the Metronome sits, and originally the base for the short-lived statue of Stalin from which the plaza takes it popular name. One of the best write ups on the history of the statue can be found here. The Stalin Plaza site is vast, as the Google Maps satellite image shows. It is unclear how long it will be shut for skateboarders, and how much will be inaccessible while repairs take place. There are already condolence messaged on the Slap forum.

Immediately skateboarders have sprung to action and organised a rally at Stalin Plaza for Sunday. A Facebook group to save Stalin has over 800 people planning to attend, and thousands more interested. Yet, there is plenty of discussion if this is wise. If the site is dangerous should a mass of people converge upon it? In answer, the protest is planned below the podium, in the safe area. It also seems to be focussed on making sure that the plaza is preserved in good order, not transformed, or worse still removed as a skateboarding site. There has been discussion surrounding the fate of Stalin with talk of a new museum or even aquarium at the location...

One thing is for sure, Stalin is a beloved place. It is internationally recognised as a site of skateboard pilgrimage and is able to charm every skateboarder that visits. I will sign out with footage from the Primitive crew demo at Stalin from last month.
